docs.lead_paragraph: On a wall near the entrance to Columbia University's School of International Affairs, someone has scrawled ''CIA Out of Central and South America.'' At Northwestern University, outside of Chicago, a faculty member was denied tenure after she had disrupted a speaking engagement by anti-Sandinista guerrilla leaders from Nicaragua. Recalling the ferment generated by the war in Vietnam, the heated national debate over United States policy toward countries such as El Salvador and Nicaragua has sparked intense interest and reflection on the nation's campuses. But this interest is manifested in much more than demonstrations. It has also resulted in increases in enrollments in courses on Latin American history, economics, politics, religion and anthropology and in the introduction of major new programs and institutes of Latin American studies at several schools. In addition it has raised questions among specialists in the field as to how and what to teach about Latin America in an atmosphere that is so politically charged.

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Senate's vote two weeks ago to extend the sale of subsidized wheat exports to the Soviet Union and China, vigorously opposed by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Australian Government, has also led to dismay on the table-flat Canadian prairie. The vote was followed by President Reagan's decision on Friday to authorize the sale of 3.85 million metric tons of subsidized wheat to the Soviet Union. ''If you're going to drop prices that way, we're going to follow,'' said Lorne Parker, who, with his son, farms 2,100 acres in Manitoba's Red River Valley. ''And we will do so until we go broke.'' The Senate action on July 22 -which has been supported by the House Agriculture Committee - has drawn stiff protests from Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, as well as Australian Prime Minister Robert Hawke, who object strenuously to subsidized sales to Moscow and Peking. Although both countries' share of the world wheat trade has risen this decade at the expense of the Americans, they decry the havoc the raging wheat war between the United States and Europe is wreaking on their own farmers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States and the European Community failed today to resolve a lingering dispute over citrus and pasta products, and the community warned that a major trade war could break out if the impasse continued. Negotiations over the weekend between the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, and the community's External Relations Commissioner, Willy de Clercq, broke down after the two sides fell short of a compromise over a lowering of European Community tariffs on American citrus products and a reduction of community subsidies for pasta exports. Mr. de Clercq issued a statement saying the talks had been ''detailed and difficult,'' adding that he and Mr. Yeutter would report back to their respective authorities and hoped to resume the negotiations this week.

docs.lead_paragraph: By the time an amnesty permitted Fernando Gabeira and other former guerrillas to return home from exile in 1979, there was already a consensus among Brazilian leftists that the armed struggle had been a mistake. Yet, with the renown that he had earned by taking part in the kidnapping of a United States Ambassador here a decade earlier, Mr. Gabeira was expected to assume a role of leadership in the traditional left's new nonviolent bid for power. Instead, the slim, soft-spoken writer chose a different kind of campaign: in books, lectures and interviews, he began bombarding this society with ideas transplanted from Western Europe and assaulting the orthodoxy of Brazil's array of small Marxist parties. ''I wanted to show that we were defeated historically and could not just offer our suffering but had to offer something different,'' he said, adding a sharp aside about the established leftist parties: ''They're always the same. They never change.'' Guru or Opportunist?

docs.lead_paragraph: THE LAST DANCE The eight-week-long Clark Center Summer Dance Festival will end this week with performances by Carmen de Lavallade, the Charles Moore Dance Theater, Lenore Latimer and the George Faison Dancers. Ms. de Lavallade, in a solo performance, will dance ''Sarong'' by Lester Horton. ''Takia,'' a traditional African dance, and ''Traces,'' a medley of black American dances, will be performed by the Charles Moore Dance Theater. Ms. Latimer will dance ''Repeated Solo.'' The George Faison Dancers will perform ''Suite Otis,'' a dance Mr. Faison choreographed in 1971 to the music of Otis Redding. This work will be performed under the rubric of the Faison company by 15 dancers, including Gary DeLoatch, of the main company of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Latin in Manhattan, they're acting, singing, dancing. At least, the 400 of them who are here for the Festival Latino in New York are doing just that in what has become one of the world's most important arenas for Hispanic performing arts. The festival, which runs through Aug. 31 with representatives from more than a dozen countries, occupies the outdoor Delacorte Theater and the downtown Public Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival -whose leader, Joseph Papp, has been the guiding light of this annual event. This is the 10th anniversary of the first Festival Latino, which was put together on a shoestring $25,000 budget. It was not until the next one, in 1980, that the festival settled in as a yearly feature of summer life in New York. This year, with a budget of more than $1 million and running for 26 days, the festival is presenting 34 companies - six musical, four dance and the rest theatrical - along with more than 20 films, most of them new to New York, and two weeks of video.

docs.lead_paragraph: At the initiative of Colombia's newly inaugurated President, eight Latin American nations announced plans today to revive their stalled peace efforts in Central America. A statement said the eight nations' Foreign Ministers would meet ''as soon as possible'' to develop a fresh strategy intended to break the deadlock in negotiations between Nicaragua and its neighbors. The regional mediators are from the four nations of the so-called Contadora Group - Colombia, Mexico, Venezuela and Panama - and four other countries - Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Peru - that agreed last year to offer active support to the Contadora initiative.

And it could smooth relations at next month's meeting on international trade in Punta del Este, Uruguay, under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

docs.lead_paragraph: Can Latin American democracies build a common market modeled on the European Community? That's what Argentina and Brazil would do with a tariff union intended to increase and reorient trade and make political partners out of longtime rivals for regional dominance. Argentina and Brazil are two of Latin America's richest, most developed countries. They can be self-sufficient in food and energy, as well as a variety of competitively produced industrial goods. Their new democracies, supported by substantial middle classes, are also the continent's most firmly rooted.
